item.title: Higher Death Toll Feared in Vanuatu in Wake of Tropical Cyclone Pam
item.description: Aid workers on the ground said the tiny nation’s capital had been flattened after the powerful storm tore through the archipelago.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Port-Vila, the capital of Vanuatu, was in ruins after Tropical Cyclone Pam ripped through, but the extent of damage elsewhere in the South Pacific island nation was not easily determined.

item.title: Chinese Premier Vows Tougher Regulation on Air Pollution
item.description: Premier Li Keqiang acknowledged that there was a gap between the government’s efforts and public ire about pervasive smog.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG and CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Myanmar Is Issued Warning by Chinese Premier Over Bombing Deaths
item.description: China’s premier, Li Keqiang, condemned the deaths of four Chinese farmers killed by a bomb from a Myanmar warplane.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: Bus Plunges Off Cliff in Brazil, Killing Scores of Passengers
item.description: At least 40 people were killed after the driver of the bus carrying families to an evangelical Christian event in Paraná State lost control, officials said.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO
item.media:credit: Salmo Duarte/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images, via Agencia RBS
item.media:description: Firefighters at the scene of a fatal bus crash on Saturday in the southern Brazilian state of Santa Catarina.

item.title: Cyclone Hits Island Nation of Vanuatu, Killing 8
item.description: Tropical Cyclone Pam bore down on the island nation of Vanuatu with winds of around 160 miles an hour.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: Yachts damaged by Cyclone Pam in Port-Vila, Vanuatu, on Saturday.

item.title: Americans Evacuated From Sierra Leone After Possible Ebola Contact
item.description: The group of 10 aid workers, with the group Partners in Health, may have come in contact with the virus in Sierra Leone, officials said.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: Modi Visits Tamils’ Cultural Heart in Tour of Sri Lanka
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi became the first Indian prime minister to visit Jaffna, a city that is still struggling to recover from decades of war between Tamil rebels and the central government.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in Colombo, Sri Lanka.

item.title: Breaking Silence, Survivor Sets Out to Meet Holocaust Past
item.description: Tomi Reichental, who was sent to a concentration camp as a child, has mesmerized students in Ireland with his stories of wartime atrocities.
item.dc:creator: DOUGLAS DALBY
item.media:credit: Paulo Nunes dos Santos for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tomi Reichental, a 79-year-old survivor of Bergen-Belsen now living in Ireland, is the subject of a film titled “Close to Evil.”

item.title: Swedish Prostitution Law Targets Buyers, but Some Say It Hurts Sellers
item.description: More than 15 years after it criminalized the purchase of sex while allowing its sale, Sweden continues to grapple with issues that could limit progress in reducing prostitution and trafficking.
item.dc:creator: DAVID CROUCH

item.title: Sierra Leone Official Seeks Asylum in United States
item.description: Vice President Samuel Sam-Sumana said that he had requested asylum at the American Embassy after soldiers surrounded his home in the wake of his expulsion from the governing party.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Nun Raped During Robbery at Convent School in India
item.description: Men armed with knives broke into the Convent of Jesus and Mary in Ranaghat and stole about $9,000 in cash and valuables, a police official said. One of them raped the nun, the Catholic archbishop of Kolkata said.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Chinese General Warns Myanmar Over Bombing
item.description: A Chinese military commander warned of a strong response unless Myanmar prevented warfare with ethnic rebel groups from spilling into Chinese territory, deepening the tensions between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: An Ever-Bleaker Syria, From All Vantage Points
item.description: Syria enters its fifth year of conflict amid a growing humanitarian crisis that is echoing far from its borders.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed buildings in Homs. About half of Syria’s prewar population has fled, the United Nations says, and nearly four million people are refugees abroad.

item.title: Iran Negotiators Face Late Obstacles to a Deal
item.description: The remaining issues in the talks on Iran’s nuclear program include when economic sanctions would be lifted and how inspections would be conducted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, right, was to return to Switzerland for a critical round of talks.

item.title: C.I.A. Cash Ended Up in Coffers of Al Qaeda
item.description: The United States, largely because of poor oversight and loose financial controls, has sometimes inadvertently financed the very militants it is fighting.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:description: President Ashraf Ghani, center, with former President Hamid Karzai, left, whose government received monthly C.I.A. payments.

item.title: 33 Die After Myanmar Ferry Capsizes
item.description: Huge waves slammed the vessel, which sank near Myebon in Rakhine State late on Friday.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.S. to Decide Soon on Restoring Military Aid to Egypt
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry spoke at a conference to convey American support for promises of economic liberalization for Egypt.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry speaking in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, on Saturday.

item.title: Vindication After a Battlefield Error and Purple Hearts Long Denied
item.description: Decades after Dan Jones’s last flight over Vietnam ended in wreckage and blood, his effort to see that his fallen Marine crew members be honored is reaching its end.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.media:description: Dan Jones during a ceremony in which the Purple Heart was awarded to First Lt. Glenn J. Zamorski, his fellow crew member and one of three Marines killed in a helicopter crash in Vietnam.

item.title: Poles Steel for Battle, Fearing Russia Will March on Them Next
item.description: Paramilitary groups in Poland have experienced sharp spikes in membership since Russia began meddling in Ukraine last year, and anxiety is apparent nationwide.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN
item.media:credit: Piotr Malecki for The New York Times
item.media:description: Children played soccer as young members of the Shooters Association trained at a school in Kalisz.

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Inmate Dies in State Custody
item.description: A man arrested last year during antigovernment demonstrations died in state custody, apparently in a suicide that his family said Friday was the result of harsh prison conditions and unjust punishment.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
